All righty. This one comes from Reggie. >> What up, Re? >> Hey, Riley. I've been a bit confused about grip pressure. Sorry if it's been
explained before. I keep hearing different things. Some people say to hold it really lightly, like a tube of toothpaste, but others say you need a firm grip, especially with the lead

depend on um it depends on how how much speed you you're needing in your swing. If you
have really high speed, your grip pressure is going to go up. You have to hold on to the son of a gun. Um, hence
like in putting you will see every single player on the LPGA Tour, Liv, PGA Tour, their grip pressure on the putter
throughout the entirety of the swing um is going to be lighter uh than than driver. It just is. And a lot of that is
because I've got this thing like if I'm turning here going boom, this thing wants to shoot out away from me. Well, if it's going out of way, dog, I got to
hold on to that thing. Otherwise, it's going to fly right out of my hands, right? Like, think of it this way. This might be an easy way. If you just coat
your grip with Vaseline, with a putter, wouldn't really bother you too much at all. If you did that with driver, man, that sucker is going to be flying out of
there. So, your grip pressure does need to elevate. Now, will the grip pressure change throughout
the swing? Yeah, it will on with full swing dynamics. It it will absolutely change. It'll change with the left to the right because at the end of the day,
the hub point, which is the point uh where the left hand and the right hand meet, we're going to have a heck of a lot more pressure in a certain portion

like how that how the pressure is leveraged in here. And you'll also have plenty of pressure right into the the carpal bone on the lead hand uh under

shoots out. So it's the same thing with the feet. If you if you're on a pressure mat, you would be able to trace like where
your foot pressure is going like on the ground throughout all of that. If you had a grip that could track that pressure in your hands, you're going to see where all that pressure throughout
the swing is migrating. It's dynamic. It moves. But just from a simple perspective, I would say like whatever the pressure is. Okay, this I think this
would be a pretty easy way to to map this when you're swinging it like from in the load phase all the way through the hit. How much am I am I going to
need to to pressure the grip to hold on to it? That's pretty much what you want to start with. Okay, pressure in the handle doesn't

it's pro probably going to be a grain item that you're just into the grain. So that leading edge is going to catch. Um,

um first rather than toe side first. So, heel side's entering first. I mean, you got this spoon right here that's just going
to catch. So, it's going to dig. Um number two, if you are utilizing like let's say that I put the whole so sole on the ground, the surface area that I'm
using is massive right here when it comes to the leading edge and the entire sole. So, I'm going to have all of that interaction with the turf. So, I'd love

it won't dig as much. Number two, it's working. I I think a lot of players don't really understand the difference

are the same. That's not the case. This is the bounce. This is the sole. That's the leading edge. So, when you set the club down,
like let's say that's the that's the ground. I want you to set going to catch that into the into the turf and it will
grab. If I'm using just the sole, which is kind of hard to do because you have to have the the leading edge and the bounce um into the ground at the same
time, uh it won't dig as much. But then if I'm using the bounce, this is and this is me, in my opinion, I think it's it's mislabeled. If we call this the
glider, it would almost like get onto the turf and then just glide along the turf. We're not going to have any of that like heavy
interaction with the ground. So, and you can and you can still hit very drivebyy shots this way, but if you
take a look at like how that golf club's sitting right there, like right now, the leading edge is perpendicular to the camera. Now, it's more open to the

the bounce side of the toe, and drive it into the ground. So I can have like crazy steep AOA
